message: By now, trying to pin down what "cloud computing" means is a futile endeavor.
What's the difference between Application Service Providing and Cloud Computing?
I think that Cloud Computing most often uses massively parallel computing whereas ASPs often deal with consistent loads so that it can handle it on a single server.
It's a question in an exam we had in university. I can not find any real answer to it. And I also think that everyone has a little different understanding what CC really is.
I think Cloud is a wider terminology for something in which ASP would be a part of. SaaS sounds a bit like ASP. So I think ASP is SaaS which is part of CC.
While "cloud" tends to lead towards some amazingly scalable and distributed system, it's often just applied to any sort of hosting to make it sound cooler.

If you use the "application" part of the name as a guidepost, the distinction would be that "cloud computing" is a vague description of a platform for hosting applications, where an "application service provider" is someone who offers a network-based service/application that they would (these days) claim resides in "the cloud"

the term "Cloud" comes from the illustration of the internet in technical diagrams.  It is a catch all much like "Agile" that does not really have a strict definition.  Much like SOA.  It's a term to lead you to an idea - but nothing strict behind it.  In other words....bullshit.  Fad.  Buzzwords.  A way to sell books. :D

I would say that cloud computing is "infrastructure as a service", so an Application Service Provider can provide IaaS (although ASP is usually focused on Software as a Service). Basically: buzzwords and hype :)

I would guess ASP would be "platform as a service", something like Microsoft Azure or Google/Amazon's collective offerings where you do not have to manage the boxes.  Cloud Computing would be "infrastructure as a service", something like Amazon EC2 or Rackspace cloud where you do not have to manage the hardware.  But I agree with the above, buzzwords and hype
